awd_titl_txt: The Intracluster Mass Function from Brown Dwarfs to Stellar-Mass Black Holes from the Microlensing Fluctuations of an Extremely Magnified Star
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will take advantage of the gravitational bending of light to observe a very distant galaxy whose image is being magnified by the gravity of a cluster of galaxies in the foreground. By carefully studying the magnification of the distant galaxy they will learn about the mass distribution in the foreground cluster. This galaxy is unique because one star in that galaxy has been magnified enough to be seen at a distance of billions of lightyears. By observing changes in brightness of this star, they will learn about the masses of stars in the foreground cluster of galaxies. The project will also develop several exhibits for he Bell Museum at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities.

The project will compare different lens mass models with the surface brightness spatial variations across the lensed galaxy images to determine the most accurate mass distribution map of the lensing cluster. By obtaining a 3-year light curve for the single, highly magnified star, using the Large Binocular Telescope, they will be able to measure microlensing light fluctuations that can be used to constrain the mass function of the intracluster stars in the foreground cluster. This will help place constraints on the initial mass function.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Galaxy clusters are the most massive structures in the universe that are gravitationally bound. As light from a background source passes through a galaxy cluster, matter in the cluster causes the path of the light to bend, which can magnify background galaxies. We have studied a distant galaxy where an individual star can be detected due to its extreme magnification by the galaxy cluster.  Changes in the star’s brightness depend upon the population of stars and dark matter in the galaxy clusters. To determine how highly magnified the star is, in order to interpret its variations in brightness, we studied regions of glowing gas known as HII regions in the galaxy using the Keck Telescope and Large Binocular Telescope. 


In nearby galaxies, the luminosity of an HII region increases the velocity of the gas. HII regions with rapidly moving gas are more luminous. Our intention was to use this relationship to measure the magnification of the background galaxy using a new and independent technique. 


We concluded, however, that the HII regions in the distant galaxy may not follow the relation observed in nearby galaxies.  Indeed, our best explanation of our observations is that they appear to be more luminous than expected for their velocities. Consequently, the HII regions in the distant galaxy and perhaps many at earlier epochs of the universe’s evolution may differ from those in the nearby universe.


We have also performed a precise measurement (6%) of the expansion rate of the universe using a supernova that exploded in the same galaxy. The measurement is independent of existing techniques, and provides a point of comparison into the tension between existing measurements of the expansion rate.


Finally, we discovered and analyzed a tiny galaxy visible less than a billion years after the Big Bang. The galaxy is smaller than one-thousandth the size of our Milky Way galaxy, yet is forming the same number of stars. The galaxy is highly magnified and multiply imaged, which allowed it to be detected and studied.


Last Modified: 06/14/2024
Modified by: Patrick Kelly

Image

    NASA , ESA , and P. Kelly (University of Minnesota)
    Public Domain
    Patrick Kelly
    Highly Magnified Star and Galaxy in MACS J119 Galaxy-Cluster Field
por.por_txt_cntn:
Galaxy clusters are the most massive structures in the universe that are gravitationally bound. As light from a background source passes through a galaxy cluster, matter in the cluster causes the path of the light to bend, which can magnify background galaxies. We have studied a distant galaxy where an individual star can be detected due to its extreme magnification by the galaxy cluster. Changes in the stars brightness depend upon the population of stars and dark matter in the galaxy clusters. To determine how highly magnified the star is, in order to interpret its variations in brightness, we studied regions of glowing gas known as HII regions in the galaxy using the Keck Telescope and Large Binocular Telescope.






In nearby galaxies, the luminosity of an HII region increases the velocity of the gas. HII regions with rapidly moving gas are more luminous. Our intention was to use this relationship to measure the magnification of the background galaxy using a new and independent technique.






We concluded, however, that the HII regions in the distant galaxy may not follow the relation observed in nearby galaxies. Indeed, our best explanation of our observations is that they appear to be more luminous than expected for their velocities. Consequently, the HII regions in the distant galaxy and perhaps many at earlier epochs of the universes evolution may differ from those in the nearby universe. 






We have also performed a precise measurement (6%) of the expansion rate of the universe using a supernova that exploded in the same galaxy. The measurement is independent of existing techniques, and provides a point of comparison into the tension between existing measurements of the expansion rate.






Finally, we discovered and analyzed a tiny galaxy visible less than a billion years after the Big Bang. The galaxy is smaller than one-thousandth the size of our Milky Way galaxy, yet is forming the same number of stars. The galaxy is highly magnified and multiply imaged, which allowed it to be detected and studied.					Last Modified: 06/14/2024
